nodes.text: Major infrastructure projects systematically underestimate costs and overestimate benefits, producing biased cost-benefit analyses and causing a 'survival of the un-fittest' where the worst projects get built

Major infrastructure projects have intrinsic characteristics that increase risk: long planning horizons, complex interfaces, non-standard technology, multi-actor decision making, lock-in of concepts, changing scope, and inadequate contingencies

Empirical evidence: transportation project cost overruns are large and persistent (rail avg overrun 44.7%, bridges/tunnels 33.8%, roads 20.4%; 9 out of 10 projects overrun; no improvement over 70 years)

Empirical evidence: demand and benefit forecasts are frequently inaccurate (rail passenger traffic on average 51.4% lower than forecast, road vehicle traffic average 9.5% higher; 84% of rail forecasts wrong by more than ±20%)
Consequence: Combined cost overruns and benefit shortfalls make ex ante cost-benefit analysis of major projects misleading and unreliable ('garbage in, garbage out')
Three explanatory types exist for forecasting errors: technical (mistakes, poor data), psychological (optimism bias/planning fallacy), and political-economic (strategic misrepresentation)
Technical explanations are rejected by the large-sample data: forecasting errors are systematically biased and have not improved over time, inconsistent with mere technical error
Psychological optimism bias explains some inaccuracy but is unlikely to be the primary cause because professions would learn and reduce bias over decades, which data do not show

Political-economic explanation (strategic misrepresentation) fits the data: promoters deliberately understate costs and overstate benefits to secure approval and funding, a behavior reinforced by agency problems and competition for scarce funds

Qualitative evidence from interviews and studies (UK and US) shows planners, officials, and consultants knowingly emphasize benefits and hide realistic costs because approval depends on appearing favorable, producing the formula: underestimated costs + overestimated benefits = funding
Mechanism 'survival of the un-fittest': projects that look best on paper due to misrepresentation are the ones that produce the largest cost overruns and benefit shortfalls in reality

Methodological remedy: reference class forecasting (outside view) uses statistical distributions from comparable past projects to adjust forecasts and reduce optimism bias and strategic misrepresentation

Practical result: reference class forecasting produced concrete uplifts to cost estimates (example: UK rail projects require 40% uplift for 50% acceptable overrun risk; Edinburgh Tram estimate adjusted from £320m to £400m), and has been adopted in several countries and projects

Governance remedies: institutional reforms to enforce transparency and accountability (public scrutiny, independent peer review, benchmarking, shifting appraisal away from promoters, penalties) and market controls (private finance bearing substantial risk, shared financial responsibility, strong project organization and contract-writing)

Current trends increase systemic risk: large stimulus-driven spending, rapid shift of investments to emerging economies, and rising inclusion of ICT in projects together amplify probability and scale of financial and economic disasters in infrastructure

Evidence that ICT and emerging-economy projects carry higher risks: ICT-intensive projects perform worse than other projects and rail projects in emerging economies show higher average cost overruns (e.g., rail in emerging economies 64.6% vs North America 40.8% and Europe 34.2%)

Conclusion: To avoid wasteful and potentially disastrous infrastructure investment, planners must combine outside-view forecasting methods with governance reforms that align incentives to reward accurate estimates and punish deliberate misrepresentation
